factsheet.heading: Existing Building
paragraphs: Located within the Stroud Green Conservation Area, the existing property was constructed relatively recently in 2007 as a development to replace garages. The building itself had an awkward layout compounded by poor connection between spaces, both vertically and horizontally, particularly between the external spaces.

factsheet.heading: Features
paragraphs:
The project features:
- New timber clad extension in sustainable timber construction, keeping steelwork to a minimum.
- Triple glazed aluminium sliding glazed doors.
- New staircase to link external spaces.
- Fully refurbished main roof (upgrading thermal efficiency).
- New custom kitchen in plywood with marble worktop.
- New custom joinery and refurbishment of existing internal stair.

factsheet.heading: Design
paragraphs: The project extended and refurbished the upper floor to rationalise the spaces and added an external linking staircase between the terrace and courtyard space below making both accessible and connected. The extension itself referenced another modern timber clad residential dwelling at the opposite end of the road to provide contemporary “bookends” to the traditional period terraces between. Whilst referencing, the extension does not mimic or replicate, instead expressing itself with fresh new detailing specific to the location’s context using diagonal timber set to the pitch of the angled extension.
